revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Ouvrage Saint-Roch}} {{Infobox military installation |name = Fort Saint Rocco |native_name = Forti San Rokku |location = [[Kalkara]], [[Malta]] |image = |caption = |type = [[Polygonal fort]] |coordinates = {{coord|35|53|32.97|N|14|32|16.07|E|type:landmark_region:MT|display=inline}} |ownership = |controlledby = |open_to_public = No |built = 1872–1873 (first fort)
1900 (second fort) |used = 1873–1950s |builder = [[British Empire]] |materials = [[Limestone]] and [[concrete]] |site_area = {{convert|21200|m2|abbr=on}}{{cite web|title=The American University of Malta - Preliminary Alternative Sites Evaluation Report|url=https://opm.gov.mt/en/Documents/AUM/Preliminary%20Alternative%20Sites%20Evaluation%20Report.pdf|website=Office of the Prime Minister|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151116215006/https://opm.gov.mt/en/Documents/AUM/Preliminary%20Alternative%20Sites%20Evaluation%20Report.pdf|archivedate=16 November 2015|page=8|date=August 2015}} |height = |condition = Intact |battles = [[World War II]] |events = }} '''Fort Saint Rocco''' ({{lang-mt|Forti Santu Rokku}}), also known as '''Fort Saint Roca''' on some maps, is a [[polygonal fort]] in [[Kalkara]], [[Malta]]. It is located east of [[Fort Rinella|Rinella Battery]] and seaward of the village of Santu Rokku, and forms part of the complex of shore batteries built by the [[British Empire|British]] to defend the coast east of the mouth of [[Grand Harbour]] between the 1870s and 1900s. ==History== The construction of Fort Saint Rocco started in 1872 or 1873 by the [[British Empire|British]], as part of a program of improvements to Malta's fortifications recommended in Colonel Jervois' Report of 1866 titled "Memorandum with reference to the improvements to the defences of Malta and Gibraltar, rendered necessary by the introduction of Iron Plated Ships and powerful rifled guns".{{cite web|last1=Formosa|first1=Christian|title=Colonel Jervois Report of 1866|url=http://www.maltamilitary.0catch.com/html/jervois_report.html|website=Malta Military|accessdate=23 December 2014}} The fort was built on the site of [[San Rocco Battery]], an [[artillery battery]] built by [[National Congress Battalions|Maltese insurgents]] during the [[Siege of Malta (1798–1800)|French blockade of 1798–1800]].{{cite journal|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|title=Maltese ‘siege’ batteries of the blockade 1798-1800|journal=Arx - Online Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=May 2008|issue=6|pages=34–35|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/images/stories/Arx/arx6-2008.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2015}} Fort Saint Rocco was the first [[polygonal fort]] built by the British in Malta, and the second one built in Malta overall (the first was [[Fort Tigné]] built by the Order of Saint John). The first fort, built between 1872 and 1873, was very small given the importance of the site. It was initially armed with three [[RML 11 inch 25 ton gun]]s, but these were soon replaced with [[RML 12.5 inch 38 ton gun]]s. In 1888, the fort was inspected and was described as cramped, and some alterations were proposed. Eventually, the keep most of the battery were demolished, and a much larger fort was built in its place in 1900. The new fort was armed with [[BL 9.2 inch gun Mk I–VII|BL 9.2 inch guns]]. On 17 May 1942, the fort fired at attacking Italian [[E-boat]]s and destroyed one of them.{{cite web|title=17 May 1942: Stealth E-Boat Attack Repulsed|url=http://maltagc70.wordpress.com/2012/05/17/17-may-1942-stealth-e-boat-attack-repulsed/|website=Malta: War Diary|accessdate=31 December 2014|date=17 May 2012}} The fort remained a functional military establishment until the 1950s.{{cite web|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|title=Fort St. Rocco|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/index.php/Fortifications/fort-st-rocco.html|website=MilitaryArchitecture.com|accessdate=23 December 2014|date=22 November 2010}} ==Present day== The fort is located close to [[SmartCity Malta]], a technology park which is currently under development. Care has been taken not to damage the fort during the construction of the new complex.{{cite news|title=Green measures in place for SmartCity site clearance|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20071015/local/green-measures-in-place-for-smartcity-site-clearance.1970|accessdate=23 December 2014|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=15 October 2007}} There is no public access to the fort. In May 2015, several NGOs suggested that the campus of the proposed [[American University of Malta]] should be split up between Fort St. Rocco and the nearby [[Fort Ricasoli]] and [[Fort San Salvatore]].{{cite book|title=Alternative Sites proposal for a new University Campus|date=25 May 2015|publisher=National Independent Forum for Sustainability|page=12|url=http://issuu.com/nifsmalta/docs/nifs_-_campus_alternative_sites_in_|accessdate=6 June 2015}} This proposal will not be implemented, and the campus is to be split up between Dock No. 1 in [[Cospicua]] and Żonqor Point in [[Marsaskala]].{{cite news|title='American' University to occupy Dock 1 buildings and reduced Zonqor site|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150820/local/update-3-american-university-to-occupy-dock-1-buildings-and-reduced.581335|accessdate=20 August 2015|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=20 August 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Forts in Malta}} [[Category:Polygonal forts in Malta]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1873]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1900]] [[Category:Kalkara]] [[Category:British forts]] [[Category:World War II sites in Malta]] [[Category:Limestone buildings in Malta]] [[Category:Military installations closed in the 1950s]] [[Category:19th-century fortifications]]
